intro: Pectis ritlandii, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations such as hairy leaves and a deep root system to conserve water. Its yellow flowers bloom in spring, and the plant produces small, capsule-like fruits that disperse its seeds. Pectis ritlandii is often found in rocky soils and is considered a hardy, drought-tolerant species.
